title: Poster, "Labelled 1/8 (Refugee)", 2009
medium: Laser plotter print with hand-applied stickers on paper
provenance: Mark Gowing to Cooper Hewitt, August 2014
description: Poster for the EyeSaw 2009 exhibition, from Gowing's Labelled Series. Black-and-white photo of a bespectacled, middle-aged man, pictured from the neck up. Across his face, text reads "re / fug / ee". The letters are comprised of many small red rectangular stickers, each printed with the word "SOLD" in white.
justification: This poster, one of a series of eight designed by Mark Gowing for a personal project, was inspired by Gowing’s concerned observation that “[o]ur contemporary world seems to be in a constantly heightening state of panic over people’s origins and intents.&nbsp; Judging individuals on face value seems to be an increasing concern at both a social and political level as the global melting pot takes a firm step backwards.”&nbsp; Gowing created this set of posters to highlight what he feels is the “unjust nature of labelling an individual based on their appearance.”&nbsp; Gowing sourced his images from an inexpensive, royalty free image bank and printed them at large scale in black and white using a laser plotter printer.&nbsp; He purchased off-the-shelf stickers which he then applied by hand to the surface of the poster, creating the “labels”, such as “homeless,” “religious,” and “indigenous.”&nbsp; For this poster, Gowing use red stickers printed with white letters featuring the word “SOLD” to form the word “refugee” across the face of a man in glasses.&nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph: Poster, "Labelled 1/8 (Refugee)", 2009. Laser plotter print with hand-applied stickers on paper. Gift of Mark Gowing. 2014-32-4.
